Personally chosen by the great Hydra Spirit to be its speaker, she receives many heads' worth of wisdom and is widely considered to be one of the most insightful beings in Druskenvald. Despite her station, she spends much of her nights teaching the youth how to better commune with the spirits and discover which Spirit Beast they should choose to favor—a profound rite of passage for every member of Zulrogg society.

Tazri has lived for many centuries, extending her life with Everbloom concoctions until she can find a suitable replacement to become the next speaker of the Hydra Spirit. However, when one looks upon her, it is difficult to determine her age, appearing youthful one moment and truly ancient the next. This is made more mystifying by her eccentric passion for collecting. She knows that the swamp never gives without purpose, so she takes any trinket or debris she finds and adds it to the stitched sack that holds her collection. It is said that these odds and ends become the most powerful reagents in her rituals.

entries.name: Sister Gizzard
entries: In the twisted boughs of the deepest and most overgrown mire of Zulrogg is the thorn-tangled roost of Sister Gizzard. This fleshy, wrinkled witch with feathered, avian features resembles a bloated vulture and fittingly has a voracious appetite to consume raw, rotting flesh, especially that of sapient mortal species. She loves nothing in the world but her "children," the countless grotesque carrion birds that she commands in huge flocks through the skies of Druskenvald. They serve as eyes and ears for the Coven of the Midnight Moon and can devour the flesh off of a victim's bones in seconds.

Her witchcraft specializes in rot, decay, and disease, and it perfectly prepares any creature for consumption—including supernatural beings, spirits, or gods. It's this ability that makes Gizzard feared by all her sisters and even her mother, since she fully absorbs and claims the power of whatever entity she eats. In Zulrogg, her hungry eyes are set on the mightiest Spirit Beasts, and she hopes to eventually make a meal out of each of them to take the full primal power of the province for herself.

entries.name: Gurash'Atal
entries: While many settlements are nestled throughout the swamps, jungles, and waterways of the province, the largest of the stilted cities is Gurash'Atal {@i (gur-OSH uh-TALL)}. Built atop the murky water and throughout the mossy trees, the wooden streets and structures are connected by an elaborate network of walkways and rope bridges that are intimidating to visitors but easily navigated by locals. Long-necked reptilian swamp beasts ferry travelers to different parts of the city, and great saber-toothed felines serve as mounts that can easily climb up and down the city's various levels and leap between treetop platforms.

Throughout Gurash'Atal, shrines are dedicated to the numerous Spirit Beasts, where offerings can be made to earn their favor and even receive mystical blessings. Swampstalker Lodge draws visitors from across Druskenvald to see the greatest trophies of Zulrogg's long line of legendary hunters and learn tracking, hunting, and trapping from the masters. The bustling trading post run by the enigmatic Trader Senj has everything one needs for an expedition into the wilds.

entries.name: Sunken Temple of Rakan'Zahl
entries: Built millennia ago by a lost civilization, the ancient stone temple of Rakan'Zahl {@i (ruh-KAHN ZAHL)} slowly sunk into the swamp until it was completely swallowed by its stagnant waters. However, the chambers within have not flooded, and those who find the temple's hidden entrance can discover a labyrinthian network of hallways, ritual rooms, and grottos overtaken by the flora and fauna of the bog.

This place of ancient mystical power has also drawn the attention of a cult that worships the malevolent Bloodbat Spirit. They practice their malign rites in the damp stone chambers and seek to use the temple's secret knowledge to help their patron become a god that rules all Spirit Beasts. They work toward a monumental ritual that would drain the blood and life essence of every person in the province to initiate and fuel this ascension to godhood.

entries.name: Adventures in Zulrogg
entries: Venture into the depths of Zulrogg's overgrown swamps, where spirits call and ancient dangers await those brave enough to test the swamp's primal powers.

entries.caption: Zulrogg Quest Hooks
rows: Sister Gizzard's carrion birds are devouring bogborn villagers. A desperate chieftain seeks help in expelling these malevolent flocks and discovering their ultimate purpose.
Investigate the Pallid Rot fungus corrupting swathes of the swamp. A renowned herbalist suspects an ancient curse and needs help to find its source.
Delve into a sunken temple where a sinister sect worships the Bloodbat Spirit, aiming to elevate it to godhood. A concerned elder begs for a disruption of their rituals.
Accept the Swampsaber Spirit's challenge to tame wild panthers as mounts. A respected beast master provides the necessary training and tools.
Tazri Swampcaller worries about the silence from the Hydra Spirit. Explore the ethereal realms to reconnect with this sacred entity.
Address the mysterious demise of a dragon turtle washed ashore and filled with eldritch parasites. A sage seeks assistance to investigate this anomaly and prevent a disaster.
Track an immortal bogborn cannibalizing his kin in the swamp's heart. A tracker offers guidance to take down this menace.
An allegiance must be decided when big game hunters clash with a protective swamp Elemental. The huntmaster offers a reward for help, while a spirit priest stresses the Elemental's importance.
Participate in Gurash'Atal's festival of Swamp Spirits, impress a spirit in its trial, and win a rare boon. The master of ceremonies will introduce the challenges.
Retrieve a sailor's body from a shipwreck for a heartbroken fortune teller who promises a valuable reading or boon in return.
A rogue spirit priest has absorbed the Whippoorwill Spirit's power, trapping souls for his malicious designs. A seer asks for aid to free the souls and end his tyranny.
Infiltrate a rising army of bogborn thralls under a Spirit Naga's sway in an ancient city. A rebel leader recruits support to either broker peace or end the Naga's reign.

data.name: Species
entries: Druskenvald is home to an otherworldly variety of peoples, all reborn from the spirits of the departed who found their ways to this land of moon and mists. Most of these souls arrived on the {@i Ghostlight Express}, but other Strangers bring wayward souls safely through the mists to live again under the Crooked Moon. The species presented in this chapter are those who arise in the 13 provinces of Druskenvald. While each are most plentiful in the province of their origin, many folks of these species have migrated and drifted to other provinces and could be found in every corner of Druskenvald.

entries.name: Variant: Humanoid Creature Types
entries: Several of the species presented here are creature types other than Humanoid, such as the ghoulish, Undead graveborn. These type differences reinforce the unusual nature of these species, but they also come with concerns that can make these species more powerful than others. Not being a Humanoid makes a character immune to the {@spell Charm Person|XPHB} spell, for example. Conversely, it potentially makes them susceptible to other effects, such as the {@spell Protection from Evil and Good|XPHB} spell. If the GM or players are uncomfortable with these deviations from standard species, changing the creature type to Humanoid solves the dilemma, while the species' other traits preserve their narrative.

data.name: Subclasses
entries: There is great power in Druskenvald for those willing to claim it, often tapping into the old, the eerie, and the uncanny. While many of the wicked and crooked denizens of the realm turn the might and magic of the eternal night toward sinister machinations that bring horror, death, and destruction, just as many would-be heroes take up these powers to protect their homes and loved ones. However, when it comes to the strange and often grim abilities wielded in Druskenvald, morality is never clear, and there is always the chance that they can lead toward a path of darkness despite the best intentions.

Native inhabitants of Druskenvald are more naturally inclined toward these powers, but outsiders who travel to the realm through the Shroud can just as easily discover and harness them. This has led to a wide variety of folk from across the realm and even in the lands of the living that embrace and unleash these fearsome abilities.

entries.name: Folk Horror Subclasses
entries: This chapter presents Folk Horror subclasses for each of the 12 core classes, weaving the themes and inspirations of the genre into characters who can serve as protagonists of their own dreadful folktale. You can find a list of these options and a brief summary of each listed below.

entries.caption: Folk Horror Subclasses
rows: Barbarian
{@subclass Experiment|Barbarian|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Path of the Experiment}
Unleash strange modifications to the body
Bard
{@subclass Whistles|Bard|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|College of Whistles}
Whistle up ghostly companions
Cleric
{@subclass Harvest|Cleric|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Harvest Domain}
Channel the divine through harvest cycles
Druid
{@subclass Old Ways|Druid|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Circle of the Old Ways}
Unleash the primeval forest's power
Druid
{@subclass Wicker|Druid|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Circle of Wicker}
Weave primal magic through wicker effigies
Fighter
{@subclass Barrow Guard|Fighter|XPHB|CrookedMoon24}
Command prowess from beyond the grave
Monk
{@subclass Pestilent Haze|Monk|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Warrior of the Pestilent Haze}
Harness plague against your foes
Paladin
{@subclass Castigation|Paladin|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Oath of Castigation}
Burn away wickedness with righteous fire
Ranger
{@subclass Grim Harbinger|Ranger|XPHB|CrookedMoon24}
Mark foes with a hound of doom
Rogue
{@subclass Sinner|Rogue|XPHB|CrookedMoon24}
Bend fate and hex foes through jinxcraft
Sorcerer
{@subclass Crimson|Sorcerer|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Crimson Sorcery}
Manipulate blood and vitality of allies and enemies
Warlock
{@subclass Great Fool|Warlock|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Great Fool Patron}
Harness chaotic laughter to confound foes
Warlock
{@subclass Horned King|Warlock|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Horned King Patron}
Practice witchcraft to deliver curses and boons
Wizard
{@subclass Occultist|Wizard|XPHB|CrookedMoon24}
Draw power from forbidden knowledge
Wizard
{@subclass Philosopher|Wizard|XPHB|CrookedMoon24}
Master fundamental truths of creation through alchemy

images.title: {@subclass Old Ways|Druid|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Circle of the Old Ways}
{@subclass Pestilent Haze|Monk|XPHB|CrookedMoon24|Warrior of the Pestilent Haze}

entries.name: Folk Horror Class Theming
entries: If you do not wish to select one of the aforementioned subclasses, there are numerous ways to flavor any subclass with the themes of Folk Horror to ensure that your character feels thematically appropriate in the setting and story of the Crooked Moon. Below are options to consider when applying Folk Horror theming to all twelve core classes.

entries.caption: Folk Horror Class Themes
rows: Barbarian
The primal rage that you unleash comes from an ancient entity of the dark woods
Bard
You weave your spells by singing folk songs, performing folk dances, or sharing folklore
Cleric
The deity you worship is an ancient and mostly forgotten god honored at natural shrines
Druid
Your circle conducts its rituals in the most remote and isolated parts of the wilderness
Fighter
The fighting style you practice was passed down by an ancient, nearly extinct order
Monk
You learned your martial abilities from a secretive society that operates in the shadows
Paladin
The oath you swore and the tenets you hold are rooted in superstition and folklore
Ranger
You are a wanderer able to survive in the most isolated and wild places of the world
Rogue
You use stealth and subterfuge to advance the aims of a mysterious, hidden cult
Sorcerer
The event that granted you sorcery was inexplicable and uncanny, leaving you haunted
Warlock
You practice the magic granted by your patron through archaic rituals and sacrifices
Wizard
You learned your arcane arts from lost and forbidden knowledge you unearthed

data.name: Backgrounds
entries: This chapter presents Folk Horror backgrounds for level 1 characters with strong ties to Druskenvald. If you select one of these backgrounds, you gain the feat specified in the description. If the background you choose for a Druskenvald campaign does not provide a feat, you gain a bonus {@book Origin feat|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Origin Feats} of your choice from those presented in this book, or your choice of {@filter Origin feat|feats|category=O} from the {@link 5th Edition core rules|https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/br-2024}.
Some of the backgrounds presented here provide you with a rare language.

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: When you create a character using one of the backgrounds in this chapter, increase one of your starting ability scores by 2 and another by 1, or increase three scores by 1 each. These increases can't raise a score above 20.

entries.name: Amnesiac
entries: Some portion of your past has been swallowed by nothingness. The missing time could be a short interval—mere days or weeks gone from your memory—or you might have only vague hints at best of who you are and where you are from. Flashes of dÃ©jÃ  vu are common, taunting you with recollection, but they almost always slip away, as ungraspable as the mists of Druskenvald. An injury, some traumatic experience, or the magical workings of a spell or curse could be the culprit behind your amnesia.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Memory Starved|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Memory Starved}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: Choose two (see below)

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Choose one (see below)

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Book|XPHB} (personal notes), {@item Ink|XPHB}, {@item Ink Pen|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 11 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Scattered Memories
entries: You don't choose skill proficiencies or a tool proficiency when you select this background, and you don't determine the two languages that are part of your origin—these are parts of your past that you are missing. Instead, you can pick one of those proficiencies or the languages during play at any time. The knowledge might return in a spontaneous flash, even as you make a roll that relies on the proficiency, or slowly emerge as you struggle to solve a problem. Once you choose one of these features, you can't choose another one until you gain a level.

The GM might rule that you can choose a new recalled feature early if something reminds you of your past, such as finding a piece of evidence from your missing memories or experiencing an event similar to one you have forgotten. Of particular value is an event relating to one of the story threads or trinkets presented below.

entries.name: Building an Amnesiac
entries: Any character can face misfortune or a choice that steals their memory. Consider how your character came to lose their memory. Was it lost through injury or illness, or did something more sinister steal it with a toxin or curse? You might decide to leave this choice up to the GM, letting you as a player discover the cause alongside your character.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: This background presents a paradox when considering threads to weave through a campaign, since the character may not remember them. Work with the GM to create some leading events or people that can serve as constants to trace a path through the void of the character's past, especially if the GM can insert existing nonplayer characters into the thread to strengthen these connections. The Amnesiac Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of these threads.

entries.caption: Amnesiac Story Threads
rows: You have recurring dreams of someone you might recognize on your adventures.
You absent-mindedly doodle the same design or symbol over and over.
A friend has been traveling the provinces of Druskenvald with a caravan, searching for any hint of your past as they do.
A rhyme or song you've never heard before comes to mind when your thoughts wander.
Rainbow colors, such as those on a soap bubble or oil slick, fill you with unexplained terror.
You have a fragmented recollection of traveling to a remote place in the mountains.

entries.name: Amnesiac Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Amnesiac Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Amnesiac Trinkets
rows: Half of a tarnished silver ring with a partial inscription in a language you don't understand
A music box that plays a sad tune you recognize but can't identify
A short note addressed to you signed with a name you don't recognize
A thin silk scarf with a fading scent that stirs familiarity
A toy horse with unfamiliar initials inked on it
A locket whose portrait is burnt and unrecognizable

entries.name: Crimson Aspirant
entries: You have delved into the forces that animate all life—even those that counterfeit life, such as Constructs and Undead. Many of these studies concentrate on the nature of blood and its power to sustain life and transmit vital essence, binding the soul to the flesh. You might have apprenticed under a sly-hearted mentor or a secret cabal focused on understanding or even manipulating life and death. You may have learned from a detailed treatise that you've put into practice, daring to become versed in the forbidden arts.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Crimson Ritualist|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Crimson Ritualist}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Arcana|XPHB}, {@skill Medicine|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Herbalism Kit

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Fine Clothes|XPHB}, {@item Healer's Kit|XPHB}, 3 {@item Vial|XPHB|Vials}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Crimson Aspirant
entries: Characters who value study and learning, as well as those with a capacity to heal the injuries and illnesses of others, readily become crimson aspirants. More physically inclined characters can be drawn to the teachings of blood to tap into their increased vital energies, as can those who are sickly or weak in hopes of overcoming that adversity.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Crimson Aspirant Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Crimson Aspirant Story Threads
rows: Sometimes when you bleed, you hear whispers from your fallen blood that tease with meaning.
You were trained by a remote monastery, but your mentor ushered you out one morning in a panic and sent you away.
A plague carried in the blood defies cures, and you must find its origin.
Your mentor, who inducted you into the secrets held within life and blood, vanished suddenly.
Your studies reveal a spate of anemia cases, some ending in death, as the predations of blood-drinking monsters.
A loved one, such as a paramour or sibling, has died, and your studies hint at a way to bring them back.

entries.name: Crimson Aspirant Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Crimson Aspirant Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Crimson Aspirant Trinkets
rows: A glass pendant with a single drop of blood suspended within
A long scroll with an anatomical study and description of how life energy flows through the body
A handkerchief with a blood drop pressed into the center
A polished bloodstone for balancing vital energy
A vial of blood that never coagulates or dries
A small box of ashes said to be from a martyr who was falsely accused of vampirism and burned at the stake

entries.name: Crossroads Gambler
entries: You've made your bones on games of chance, and one day your games crossed the line into something far more serious. You might have played for your soul against a Fiend, matched wits with ancient forest Fey in a riddle contest, or rolled dice with the fabled Mister Crossroads.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Fate Gambler|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Fate Gambler}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception|XPHB}, {@skill Insight|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Choose one kind of Gaming Set

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) Gaming Set (same as above), {@item Caltrops|XPHB}, {@item Fine Clothes|XPHB}, Fine Wine (bottle), 23 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Crossroads Gambler
entries: Characters who live by their wits, such as Rogues and Bards, find the call of a crossroads gambler appealing, though anyone could find themselves in the position of playing for stakes higher than they could ever imagine.. or pay. A spellcaster who conjured the wrong entity may find themself a gambler. The desperate who sought out a mysterious figure to throw dice and match wits for power or salvation can find their fates bound to the crossroads.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Crossroads Gambler Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Crossroads Gambler Story Threads
rows: Someone you thought was a friend tricked you into making your bargain.
You've found that if you go too long without making a wager, your luck starts to turn sour.
You only feel alive in the midst of a contest.
You lost your bet, and you're on the run from the thing surely coming to collect.
Someone close to you made a wager and lost. You made your deal to try and find them.
You've been gambling for a long time, and you're tired. Now all you want is a way out.

entries.name: Crossroads Gambler Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Crossroads Gambler Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Crossroads Gambler Trinkets
rows: A lucky coin made of a strange material, such as green steel or bone
A battered, blood-stained six of hearts playing card
A torn journal page of a long-missing gambler who was hopeful to win their fortune from a being they describe but fail to name
The preserved foot of a rabbit, owl, or weasel
A six-sided die that somehow seems to have too many 2s when closely examined
A silver-plated ivory chess rook

entries.name: Cultist
entries: You have been inducted into a secret society that venerates or pursues power from some otherworldly source. The cultists might serve as minions of an entity they worship, or they may seek to understand and claim its might for their own. Depending on the malevolence of the cult's patron or the malefic purposes they may serve, cultists could be a force of wickedness or a group of closely bonded and dedicated people who pursue a common, if esoteric, goal.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Cult Initiate|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Cult Initiate}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Arcana|XPHB}, choose one (Cultist Affinity table skill recommended)

items.name: Language:
items.entry: Choose one (Cultist Affinity table language recommended)

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Calligrapher's Supplies

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB}, {@item Costume|XPHB} (cult garb), {@item Holy Symbol|XPHB} ({@item Amulet|XPHB}: cult insignia), {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.caption: Cultist Affinities
rows: Aberration
{@skill Perception|XPHB}
Deep Speech
Celestial
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
Celestial
Fiend (Demon)
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
Abyssal
Fiend (Devil)
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
Infernal
Fey
{@skill Nature|XPHB}
Sylvan

entries.name: Cult Veneration
entries: Cults propitiate beings of otherworldly power in hopes of sharing in that potency. Choose what type of cult you joined, such as the following.

entries.name: Aberration
entries: Alien creatures with inscrutable mindsets and motivations. Many originate from outside the known multiverse.

entries.name: Celestial
entries: Beings of the Upper Planes, and paragons of order or benevolence. Many can be overbearing and uncompromising.

entries.name: Fiend (Demon)
entries: Creatures of utter evil and destruction that want to see all worlds and planes burn.

entries.name: Fiend (Devil)
entries: Beings of cunning wickedness who prize structure and obedience. They seek to subjugate others and condemn souls.

entries.name: Fey
entries: Capricious beings often associated with nature and emotional extremes. They can be beautiful, terrible, intoxicating, and horrific.

entries.name: Building a Cultist
entries: Cultists are often lost souls—individuals severed from the fabric of society whose cult became a manipulative, surrogate family. Consider if your character agrees with the aims of the cult, if they fled the group, or if they remain for infiltration purposes.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Cultist Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Cultist Story Threads
rows: You learned that the cult that took you in manipulated you throughout your life.
A member of your cult betrayed and killed your leader and mentor.
Your cult's activities aroused the ire and superstition of locals, deserved or not.
You followed a loved one into joining the cult, trying to find out what happened to them.
You met someone who forced you to see the cult you always venerated in a different light.
You joined the cult to save yourself from an incurable illness or other certain doom.

entries.name: Cultist Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Cultist Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Cultist Trinkets
rows: A sealed scroll of esoteric knowledge
A steel ball bearing etched over its entire surface with your cult's sacred text
A crystal that feels strange to the touch
A ritual knife stained with blood, sap, or oils
A set of copper tattoo needles
An embroidered cloth half mask

entries.name: Druskenvald Dweller
entries: You hail from one of the thirteen baneful provinces of Druskenvald. You might be a member of the unique species known to originate from those diverse biomes, or you may be of a different heritage altogether. The skills and culture of your home (summarized below) shape your knowledge and early experiences.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: Choose one {@book Origin feat|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Origin Feats}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Survival|XPHB}, choose one (Province Affinity table skill recommended)

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Choose one (Province Affinity table tool recommended)

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) Artisan's Tools (same as above), {@item Map|XPHB} (Druskenvald's provinces), {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.caption: Province Affinities
rows: Ardengloom
{@skill History|XPHB}
{@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}
Astramar
{@skill Arcana|XPHB}
{@item Navigator's Tools|XPHB}
Bubonia
{@skill Medicine|XPHB}
{@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}
Chernabos
{@skill Deception|XPHB}
{@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB}
Edwardia
{@skill Investigation|XPHB}
{@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB}
Enoch
{@skill Nature|XPHB}
{@item Leatherworker's Tools|XPHB}
Kalero
{@skill Performance|XPHB}
Musical Instrument
Olmarsh
{@skill Arcana|XPHB}
{@item Cartographer's Tools|XPHB|Cartographer's Supplies}
Nerukhet
{@skill Persuasion|XPHB}
{@item Weaver's Tools|XPHB}
Pholsense
{@skill Religion|XPHB}
{@item Mason's Tools|XPHB}
Picco
{@skill Performance|XPHB}
{@item Woodcarver's Tools|XPHB|Woodworker's Tools}
Syndramas
{@skill Athletics|XPHB}
{@item Cook's Utensils|XPHB}
Zulrogg
{@skill Survival|XPHB}
{@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}

entries.name: Building a Druskenvald Dweller
entries: Any sort of character can be a Druskenvald dweller. When you make your character, decide if you belong to the species associated with your home province, or if you are of another kind who was raised outside the home of most of your species. This decision itself may determine truths about your character to be experienced throughout your journeys in Druskenvald.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Druskenvald Dweller Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Druskenvald Dweller Story Threads
rows: You were left on a church doorstep as an infant. The only clue to your origin is the torn cloak used as a blanket.
You fled your home province after being accused of a crime, whether justly or not.
After hearing stories of other provinces, you struck out to see more of Druskenvald.
Members of a trade caravan stole something or harmed someone dear to you.
You made a desperate pact with an ashborn and now seek to nullify the contract.
A vicious bogborn bounty hunter trails you.

entries.name: Druskenvald Dweller Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Druskenvald Dweller Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Druskenvald Dweller Trinkets
rows: A brass needle with a dangling bit of broken thread
A dull, rusty sickle with a bone handle
A star chart etched onto a crystal plate
A wicker doll with bloodstained bead eyes
A length of chain that sometimes rattles when left unattended
A mummified hand preserved in bog peat

entries.name: Experiment
entries: You are forever altered in some drastic, physical way, perhaps even made monstrous. A blasphemous fusion of science, alchemy, and magic changed you, possibly to mend some unrecoverable malady, or to test the limits of your biology. The process was a success, at least to a point, but the change left its mark on you. The indelible warping of your form can be a source of fear for those who do not understand what they see.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Altered|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Altered}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}, {@skill Medicine|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Alchemist's Supplies

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Alchemist's Supplies|XPHB}, {@item Manacles|XPHB}, {@item Perfume|XPHB} (to cover chemical smell), {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB} (with hooded cloak), 5 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building an Experiment
entries: An experiment can come from any class or walk of life. Were you kidnapped and altered against your will, or did you volunteer for a heinous procedure? Was the experimenting done purely for discovery, to overcome a worse fate, or for someone to play at being a god? Whatever the reason, the process is never pleasant, and it always leaves scars—both those you can see and those that have marked your very soul.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Experiment Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Experiment Story Threads
rows: A particular song stirs feelings of sadness and overwhelming anger in you, reminding you of the process that changed you.
A portion of your altered body is very clearly grafted from a different person, and they might want it back.
Another person was changed alongside you. They fled before you left, urging you to do the same.
You have recurring nightmares of the procedure you endured, sometimes seeing glimpses of faces in the dream that you don't recognize.
Your physical difference invites curiosity and attention, which for some reason is more disturbing than disdain or fear.
A peculiar symbol is branded on or near your alteration.

entries.name: Experiment Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Experiment Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Experiment Trinkets
rows: A syringe with a faintly glowing purple residue
A wrench that is the only one that fits a bit of simple machinery built into your body
A sheaf of chemical-stained parchments covered in incomprehensible notes and schematics
A spool of silver thread that matches stitches in your altered body part
A metal hip flask with strange runes scratched into one side
A smooth stone that comforts and soothes you when you hold it tightly

entries.name: Ghostlight Passenger
entries: Once, even before your most recent travel to Druskenvald, you rode the deathly train known as the {@i Ghostlight Express}. Your memories of that journey might be hazy and dreamlike, or they could be sharp and jarring in their clarity. You learned some of the workings of the ghostly engine and formed a connection with the conductor and fellow travelers that has stayed with you. At times, you are even more comfortable with the dead than the living.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Ghostlight Medium|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Ghostlight Medium}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Insight|XPHB}, {@skill Persuasion|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Smith's Tools

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Smith's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Bullseye Lantern|XPHB}, {@item Fine Clothes|XPHB}, {@item Oil|XPHB} (3 flasks), 5 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Ghostlight Passenger
entries: Every person in Druskenvald travels the {@i Ghostlight Express} at least once, but very few form the deep and lasting connection that you have. Your first trip on the train might have been a near death experience from which you were saved, or perhaps you did die in earnest but were resurrected later.
Characters attuned to spirits or the lands of the dead, such as Clerics, Paladins, or those who had brushes with death, are the most common to exhibit this deep connection.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Ghostlight Passenger Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Ghostlight Passenger Story Threads
rows: Sometimes when you dream, you find yourself back on the Ghostlight Express in more than just a dream image.
Your first journey to the lands of the dead was confusing, but you realized you now may be able to find the departed spirit of a loved one once thought lost forever.
A specific spirit returns to speak to and through you repeatedly.

People sometimes speak to you as if they know you but later have no recollection of the conversation. During those moments of recognition, they know details from your visits on the Ghostlight Express.
You sometimes see people in your travels who you recognize from your time on the Ghostlight Express.
Someone greeted you with knowledge of your first journey on the Ghostlight Express, but you don't remember them.

entries.name: Ghostlight Passenger Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Ghostlight Passenger Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Ghostlight Passenger Trinkets
rows: A slate board smeared with erased chalk, where you sometimes find words scratched
A lump of coal that never burns away and gives off wispy smoke
A torn ticket stub that is slightly translucent
A dented train conductor's whistle that only the dead can hear
A pocket watch that runs backwards
A battered train conductor's hat

entries.name: Night Stalker
entries: Once you were prey, stalked by a monster through the dark of night. Now, you are the hunter, and the things which you once feared will learn the true meaning of dread. You have become far deadlier, hungrier, and crueler than the monster that once hunted you. You are, yourself, the monster now—a fearsome creature once thought to slake its hunger on you or those close to you. You survived, and your would-be killer will have its own destruction in turn.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Hunter of Hunters|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Hunter of Hunters}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Stealth|XPHB}, and one other of your choice from the following list: {@skill Arcana|XPHB}, {@skill History|XPHB}, {@skill Religion|XPHB}, {@skill Nature|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Leatherworker's Tools

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Leatherworker's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Book|XPHB} (one creature type), {@item Hooded Lantern|XPHB}, {@item Hunting Trap|XPHB}, {@item Oil|XPHB} (3 flasks), {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Night Stalker
entries: Consider how you joined the hunt against the creatures of the night. Did you lose someone close to you or survive an attack? Perhaps you were raised in a family line of dedicated hunters. Rangers, Rogues, and Barbarians make fearsome night stalkers, as does any character with a passion to oppose these deadly creatures.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Night Stalker Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Night Stalker Story Threads
rows: You're hunting the creature that slew your loved ones.
You started your hunt with zeal but quickly find that you're losing your stomach for it.
As you learn more about the creatures of the night, you discover that some of your initial thoughts about them were wrong.
You failed to stand up to a creature and saved yourself instead of someone else. Now you try to make up for that shame.
The monsters you hunt terrify you to your soul, and you lash out to deny your fear.
Your fervent hunt is a cover for your desire to become something more than mortal.

entries.name: Night Stalker Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Night Stalker Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Night Stalker Trinkets
rows: A necklace of yellowed fangs
A series of letters showing a person's personality sharply eroding into incoherence and raving
A knife made from a massive creature's claw
A casting of a monstrous footprint
A hide or pelt from a vicious beast
A glass eye that normal animals shy away from

entries.name: Reflected Wanderer
entries: You were once whole, but part of you has been separated from your being and now also wanders the world. This aspect of you took your reflection and shadow with it, and it travels about as a mirage that looks identical to you. You know this other self is out there—you can feel it—but what it wants and why is lost on you. Sometimes you encounter a stranger that knows you—for good or ill—though you've never met them before, and you can't help but wonder if they met the other you.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Unreflected|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Unreflected}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception|XPHB}, {@skill Investigation|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Disguise Kit

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Disguise Kit|XPHB}, {@item Mirror|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 16 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Reflected Wanderer
entries: Any character can be a reflected wanderer. How was it that your being came to be divided? How much do you understand about your situation? Are you truly who you think you are, or are you, in reality, the very castoff reflection of your other self?

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Reflected Wanderer Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Reflected Wanderer Story Threads
rows: A close, long-term relationship went suddenly sour as if you wronged the other person.
Your other self leaves you messages and signs as it travels, sometimes seeming fond and other times resentful.
Animals are unsettled by you, becoming skittish and restless in your presence.
You're wanted for several minor crimes you never committed, though eyewitnesses named you. Over time, more crimes of increasing severity occur.
Someone you've been at odds with begins treating you with more respect and kindness.
Mirrors sometimes crack when you touch them.

entries.name: Reflected Wanderer Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Reflected Wanderer Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Reflected Wanderer Trinkets
rows: A shattered hand mirror
An invitation to a powerful person's home whom you've never met
A locket with your silhouette painted in it on both sides, facing each other
A short, derisive letter from yourself that you don't remember writing
A brooch delivered to you that you didn't purchase
A piece of chalk that writes in a different color than it appears to be

entries.name: Rest Warden
entries: In a place closer to the lands of the dead than the living, those who tend the eternal rest and disposition of the deceased are held in a mixture of high esteem and apprehension. You have plied the trade of the gravedigger, the mortician, and the embalmer. There are times when you have been the only one to say a kind word in honor of those who passed. The depredations of the Undead are well-known to you, and you don't suffer their meddling in the rest of your charges.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Grave Keeper|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Grave Keeper}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Religion|XPHB}, {@skill Survival|XPHB}

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Mason's Tools

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Mason's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Hooded Lantern|XPHB}, {@item Oil|XPHB} (3 flasks), {@item Shovel|XPHB}, Soap, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB} (with thick gloves and dark-colored hood), 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Rest Warden
entries: Rest wardens tend to be either a dour and somber lot or—in contrast to their trade—are filled with the vibrance and joy of life. Those who understand the thin thread between life and death or who possess the strength to dig graves beneath moonlit skies and tend the bone orchards where the dead sleep are called to serve as rest wardens.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Rest Warden Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Rest Warden Story Threads
rows: A strange figure commissioned you to carve a headstone for someone who is very much in the prime of life.
In a time of desperation, you once accepted a sizeable bribe to look the other way when someone robbed a grave.
You spent time learning from Yorgrim, gravedigger and caretaker of the Maidenmist Cemetery.
Someone violated graves under your watch and stole away with the corpses.
You comforted a child at their parent's funeral and have taken a protective shine to them.
A loved one once rose from the grave as an Undead creature. You vowed to bring them to their final rest.

entries.name: Rest Warden Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Rest Warden Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Rest Warden Trinkets
rows: A prayer slip and seal covered in verses to protect the departed
A charcoal rubbing of a gravestone epitaph
A coffin nail that always ends up bent, no matter how many times you straighten it
A dried flower cleaned from one of the first graves you tended
A length of rusty iron chain and padlock
A sealed bottle containing a final breath

entries.name: Reveler
entries: For a time, you traveled with the Lord of Fools' strange and unsettling revelry. Whether you are still welcome in that company, or you've struck off on your own, your time with the troupe revealed some of its nature to you—that the Lord of Fools serves some great entity who prizes humor and merriment, often at the expense of the mighty. But he is no mere jester. Beneath the mask of mockery and merriment is a mad creature who demands sacrifice.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Reveling Fool|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Reveling Fool}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Performance|XPHB}, {@skill Stealth|XPHB}

items.name: Language:
items.entry: Choose one (Abyssal recommended)

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Choose one kind of Musical Instrument

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) Musical Instrument (same as above), {@item Ball Bearings|XPHB}, {@item Costume|XPHB} (jovial character with a laughing mask), {@item Hunting Trap|XPHB}, {@item Manacles|XPHB}, 3 {@item Torch|XPHB|Torches} (for juggling), {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Reveler
entries: The simultaneous beauty and uncomfortable truth of the revelers is that they can be anyone. Hidden by their masks and costumes, one's friends, family, servants, or lords could be capering about the ribbon-twined pole and leading impressionable folk away when the revel withdraws. How might a reveler behave differently in each guise?

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Reveler Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Reveler Story Threads
rows: Posters depicting drawings of your reveler guise have started showing up in towns after the fool's revel leaves.
Once you learned the truth of the revels—that some of the people who vanish ostensibly to join the revel are sacrificed—you seized the first chance to slip away.
Recently, more people than usual have gone missing from towns in the revel's wake.
Crows, owls, and other birds seem to cackle and laugh in your presence.
You have grown suspicious that another reveler has a sinister motive concealed by their jester's guise.
You left the revel when you caught a glimpse of the wickedness lurking beneath the Lord of Fool's jovial veneer.

entries.name: Reveler Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Reveler Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Reveler Trinkets
rows: A small wind-up bell that you can conceal in the palm of your hand with a button to activate it
A dented metal spray bottle
A string of colorful handkerchiefs tied together
A tarnished silver bell that sometimes refuses to jingle
A pair of boots or slippers that squeak comically with each step
A short scepter or baton with a horn on the cap

entries.name: Scholar of the Forbidden
entries: Delving into the brittle pages of ancient tomes and weathered tablets carved with blasphemy, you have unearthed secrets of eldritch beings of unfathomable might. Most of their meaning slips like whispers out of your grasp, but you have seized both forbidden knowledge and cursed power from them. The deeper you plunge into depravity, the more certainty you feel that you are not there alone.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Dread Speech|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Dread Speech}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Arcana|XPHB}, {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}

items.name: Language:
items.entry: Choose one (Deep Speech recommended)

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Calligrapher's Supplies

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB}, {@item Book|XPHB} (a topic of arcana), {@item Ink|XPHB}, {@item Ink Pen|XPHB}, {@item Lamp|XPHB}, {@item Oil|XPHB} (3 flasks), {@item Paper|XPHB} (10 sheets), 2 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Scholar of the Forbidden
entries: Wizards and Warlocks make the most common scholars of the forbidden, but any character who stumbles onto the dread truths waiting beneath the surface of reality can find themselves walking the path. The secrets you unveil could threaten to destabilize any number of powerful beliefs and organizations, which makes you dangerous to them.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Scholar of the Forbidden Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Scholar of the Forbidden Story Threads
rows: A wealthy patron paid you handsomely to research what led to your discoveries, and they want what you found.
When you spoke aloud the first secret word you deciphered, you passed out and woke hours later to find your lips cracked and blackened.
Something has been following you since you uncovered the illicit secrets. You sense it always behind you, drawing closer.
Your shadow converses with you when you're alone, acting as a debate partner and sounding board in your studies.
The reflections of your eyes are black voids, but no one else seems to notice.
An order of inquisitors or witch hunters hound you wherever you travel, seeking to silence you and your discoveries forever.

entries.name: Scholar of the Forbidden Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Scholar of the Forbidden Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Scholar of the Forbidden Trinkets
rows: A broken fragment of a stone table carved with symbols that seem to slither and writhe
A desiccated bit of tentacle
A small soapstone idol that always seems to end up in your pocket, bag, or otherwise on your person
A book bound in Humanoid skin with blank pages that absorb ink or other pigments
An alien eyeball floating in a jar of preservative fluid
An antique amulet with indecipherable symbols, that whispers at the edge of consciousness when worn

entries.name: Wicker Weaver
entries: You know the ancient rites kept alive by secretive druids and hedge practitioners in the shadowed groves of the primordial forests. Remedies and hexes woven into wicker charms can stave off misfortune and ward away evil. They could just as likely invite gloom and the ire of the old spirits.

items.name: Feat:
items.entry: {@book Charm Twister|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|5|Charm Twister}

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Insight|XPHB}, {@skill Nature|XPHB}

items.name: Language:
items.entry: Sylvan

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Weaver's Tools

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Quarterstaff|XPHB}, {@item Weaver's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Basket|XPHB} (with dry reeds ready to weave), {@item Book|XPHB} (druidic lore), {@item Iron Pot|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 19 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries.name: Building a Wicker Weaver
entries: Compassionate characters driven by a deep connection to the land and a passion to protect it become wicker weavers. Druids of other circles might trade knowledge with the Circle of Wicker. Healers and guardians alike may seek out the Old Ways for remedies and protective charms to ward off evil. Not all who come to the wicker craft do so with noble intent—some, broken by spite and twisted by their pain, wield the power of the wicker into malicious revenge, lashing out with curses bound in twig and bone and inflicting the wrath of the forest upon those who wronged them.

entries.name: Suggested Story Threads
entries: The Wicker Weaver Story Threads table suggests events and people who can be the start of story threads for your character that weave through the campaign.

entries.caption: Wicker Weaver Story Threads
rows: One of the charms you created ensured a baby was born healthy, and their family sends you small but heartfelt gifts.
Your mentor who taught you the craft has become increasingly withdrawn and uncharacteristically agitated.
An order of druids, the Circle of Wicker, taught you their ways. You aren't certain why.
Someone offered you a shocking sum of coin to twist a wicker charm for them. You're tempted but unsettled by the unwarranted generosity.
You traded a wicker charm for a child's toy that bound misfortune to its owner. You must keep it until you can sell it, it's stolen, or you lose it.
You wove a hex into a wicker charm to punish a criminal, and they nurse that grudge still.

entries.name: Wicker Weaver Trinkets
entries: When you make your character, you can roll once on the Wicker Weaver Trinkets table instead of on the normal starting Trinkets table.

entries.caption: Wicker Weaver Trinkets
rows: A crescent woven from wicker and laced with silver wire
A glass bauble that was the first payment you received for your hedge wisdom
A Tiny figure made of acorn caps from the oldest oak in the woods
A rough-forged knife with an etched blade
A snake skull in a wicker cage
A battered stuffed animal missing one eye

data.name: Feats
entries: This section introduces feats that connect to the Folk Horror backgrounds presented in chapter 4, though any character could take one of these with the GM's permission.

entries.name: Variant: Generalized Origin Feats
entries: Origin feats are designed to be taken at level 1, which means they are overall less powerful than General feats, but that can also make them less appealing to select at higher levels. At the GM's discretion, characters who select an Origin feat at level 4+ can add the following benefit to the feat.
Ability Score Increase. Increase one ability score of your choice by 1, to a maximum of 20.

data.name: Dark Bargains
entries: Dark Bargains weave Druskenvald's essence into the characters who dare to strike them. These ancient agreements bind the land, its magical energies, its creatures.. and you. The effects bring boon and bane alike. It may be best for some sinister characters to offer their bargains plainly, letting the lurking curses reveal themselves only when the time is right. Beware your entry into these iniquitous accords.

entries.name: Shake on It
entries: Any bargain offered by an utterly unknowable, unfathomable power such as those that position themselves within the realm of Druskenvald must be carefully considered by you, your character, and the GM. These gifts are not to be offered lightly and should not be accepted lightly; their mere presence should herald significant roleplaying opportunities now and in the future.

entries.name: Entering a Dark Bargain
entries: In nearly all cases, the power that is proposing a Dark Bargain is uninterested in negotiating the duration or eventual cost of this gift. However, there may be extenuating circumstances. There could be roleplaying scenarios or simply the current events in the adventure's narrative that could cause the power to briefly—briefly!—consider negotiating. The GM has the final say on whether a given bargainer has the inclination to haggle. Generally, characters need the Dark Bargain far more than the powers need to grant it.

In any event, Dark Bargains reflect the entity imparting them, as well as the circumstances and any prices asked in exchange. You and the GM should tailor the cosmetic details of the bargain to the character's situation.
There are multiple ways a character might be tempted with power in Druskenvald.

entries.name: Character Creation
entries: With the GM's permission, you can choose a Dark Bargain when you make your character. Work with the GM to determine the circumstances of your character entering into the bargain, who offered it, and what terms your character had to fulfill—or is still expected to fulfill—to make good on the deal.

entries.name: During Play
entries: Dark Bargains can also come about during play in a campaign. There might be times where inscrutable powers have their own designs and see an opportunity for a character to further those ends in exchange for gifts. Others might be willing to negotiate a bargain as an alternative price to death or worse.

In these cases, the GM might alter terms of the bargains, such as increasing, lessening, or even waiving the prices of the bargains entirely—though perhaps only for a short time, or as long as some other condition is met.

entries.name: Unique Bargains
entries: Each Dark Bargain is unique, and a character can enter into a given bargain only once. A character could be bound to multiple Dark Bargains at one time, but each one only once.

entries.name: Removing Dark Bargains
entries: Dark Bargains are binding once sealed. There are tales and legends of those who have outwitted a bargainer or found a way to break a bargain's hold on them, but the truth of such stories is left to the GM to decide.

data.name: Spells
entries: This chapter introduces forty spells steeped in the essence of Folk Horror. Outside of being granted these spells by features, the GM decides how player characters can learn them. For spellcasters who have access to their entire spell list, they might simply become aware of the magic of Druskenvald now available to them. Alternatively, a character might need to experience, research, or otherwise learn of a new spell before selecting it.

data.name: Appendix A: Bestiary
entries: The creatures presented in this section are special beings who can form bonds with another and serve as a familiar—not just for a spellcaster, but for anyone. This bond creates a deep, magical connection and isn't entered into lightly by these familiars. They demand respectful treatment, but in return offer loyal companionship and service. If the familiar is mistreated or wronged, it can sever the bond and may become a thorn in the side of their former companion.

Learning to form a familiar bond with one of these creatures isn't necessarily common knowledge, and you can treat discovering how to perform the ritual as a secret, as discussed in the "Monster Secrets" section in the in Appendix A of {@adventure The Crooked Moon Part Two|TheCrookedMoonPartTwo|_UNKNOWN}.

entries.name: Familiar Bond
entries: When a creature performs a 10-minute ritual using materials worth 100+ GP (noted in each familiar's subtitle), the familiar can form a magical bond with that creature to serve as its familiar. The bond ends when the creature dies, or when the familiar decides to end it (no action required). While the bond lasts, the creature and the familiar gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Bonded Sympathy
entries: The familiar can choose to exclude the bonded creature from any area of effect it creates, such as a damaging {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} or an {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} like the {@book goatstealer's Stench trait|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|8|Goatstealer}. Additionally, if the familiar has another feature that creates a bond (such as the devil's glove's {@book Symbiosis Bonus Action|TheCrookedMoonPartOne|8|Devil's Glove}), that bond forms as part of the familiar bond.

entries.name: Channel Magic
entries: When the bonded creature casts a spell with a range of touch while within 100 feet of the familiar, the familiar can take a Reaction to deliver the touch when the spell is cast.

entries.name: Telepathic Connection
entries: While the bonded creature and the familiar are within 100 feet of each other, they can communicate telepathically. Additionally, as a Bonus Action, the creature can see and hear through the familiar's senses until the start of its next turn, gaining the benefit of any special senses the familiar has.

entries.name: Revival
entries: If the familiar dies while the bond exists, the bonded creature can restore the familiar to life with all its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} by performing a 1-hour version of the Familiar Bond ritual (no further research required to learn this version).

entries.name: Fabled Heirlooms
entries: Ancient soul-binding magicks twist through the shrouded domain of Druskenvald, drawn to legendary beings with fate-touched souls. This spiritual energy weaves its way through the relics that these entities possess, imbuing them with their wielder's essence and power. Once severed from the mythic figures that shaped them, Fabled Heirlooms can be taken up by new bearers, granting strange and fearsome abilities that continue to awaken as their keepers' souls grow stronger.

Each Fabled Heirloom is a magic item that grows in strength as its attuned owner gains power. The rarity of each heirloom increases as the character grows in level, as shown on the Heirloom Rarity table. An heirloom's description details the properties it always has, as well as the properties it gains as it increases in rarity. The heirloom has all the properties of its rarity and lower.

entries.caption: Heirloom Rarity
rows: Rare
Very Rare
Legendary

images.title: {@item Idol of the Beast of Blight|CrookedMoon24}
{@item Marotte of the Lord of Fools|CrookedMoon24}
{@item Staff of Farryn of the Greenwood|CrookedMoon24}

entries.name: Cursed Curios
entries: Some magic items carry the kind of curse that worms its way into the flesh, mind, or soul, digging deeper the longer you remain attuned to it. Power is never without cost and danger in Druskenvald, but once you grasp power, do you have the courage to relinquish it?

items.name: Lingering Curses
items.entry: Ending your Attunement to one of these items removes its curse, but the power of a Cursed Curio doesn't release its hold on the user easily. If you attune to it again within 28 days, the progression of its curse returns to where it was before you ended your Attunement.

entries.name: Paranormal Potions
entries: Those who work magic in Druskenvald bind spells into potions, oils, and unguents of great power. They also know of secret practices that can exalt the base materials into draughts of greater or more lasting potency.

The potions presented here each have a Heightened Potency property. They can be found with or without the property at your discretion, and you can treat a potion with this property as one rarity higher (to a maximum of Legendary) for the purpose of determining levels at which it might be found.

entries.name: Brewing Potions
entries: The art of potion-making is practiced by hedge-wizards, swamp-witches, Old Ways herbalists, and many other folk. Characters can create paranormal potions using the normal magic item crafting rules in the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|XDMG}. Characters can also create these potions with the Heightened Potency property, or they can add the property to an existing potion that lacks it. In the rules to do so below, "you" refers to the character crafting the potion.

entries.name: Cost
entries: Adding the Heightened Potency property to a potion you're creating or to an existing potion requires extra materials, as shown in the Heightened Brewing table, beyond the cost for a normal potion of its rarity.

entries.name: Time and Ability Check
entries: Creating a potion with the Heightened Potency property takes the normal time for its rarity. Adding the Heightened Potency property to an existing potion takes 1 hour of work using {@item Alchemist's Supplies|XPHB} or an {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}. After the work time, make an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB}) check with a DC determined by the potion's rarity on the Heightened Brewing table. On a success, you create the potion without issue. On a failure, you roll {@dice 1d6} on the Potion Quirks table, then decide whether to create a potion that has the indicated quirk or discard all materials.

entries.caption: Heightened Brewing
rows: Common
10 GP
Uncommon
50 GP
Rare
500 GP
Very Rare
Legendary

entries.caption: Potion Quirks
rows: Cracked Bottles. Spend twice the normal heightened brewing cost. You can pause work on the potion to acquire more materials.
Unusual Viscosity. This potion takes an action to use instead of a Bonus Action.
Strange Feeling Inside. The drinker must expend 1 Hit Point Die as part of the Bonus Action to use this potion, or it has no effect.
Dormant Magic. This potion only provides a benefit for a drinker who can cast spells, and the drinker must expend a spell slot as part of the Bonus Action to use this potion or it has no effect.
Bitter Brew. The potion tastes so awful that the drinker must succeed a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or spit out and waste the potion.
Concentrated Draught. By strange innovation or pure luck, you've created a potion that can be used one additional time.
